III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention: (a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to: (ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/23/25, it was reported that a staff member twisted a youth's
arm and stomped on his feet.
Investigation Interviews:
On 06/23/2025, an in-person meeting was held with
Complainant. No additional concerns were reported.
In-person interviews were completed with the following at
Christ Child House on 06/23/2025, unless otherwise noted.
An interview was completed with Chief Administrator (CA). She
was advised of the investigation and the allegations were
discussed. CA reported that this morning, Youth A reported to her
that Staff 1 had twisted his arm, took his shoes and then stomped
on his feet. CA then advised that during the same conversation
with Youth A, he changed his story and stated Staff 1 did not hit
him, but did twist his arm and stomp on his feet. Lastly, before
ending their conversation, CA stated that Youth A changed his
story again and reported that Staff 1 only stomped on his feet. CA
reported she did observe sores on the feet of Youth A but stated
he has had them for a couple of days and it appears to be from
him scratching bites or sores on his feet. CA denied any concerns
with Staff 1 and denied knowledge of him being physically
aggressive with youth at the agency.
An interview was completed with Director of Residential
Services (DRS). She denied knowledge of Staff 1 being
physically aggressive with agency youth. She advised it was
reported to her that the youth ran into the conference room area,
which is prohibited space for unattended youth. The agency cook
and maintenance staff were in the area getting coffee and
contacted staff to let them know Youth A was in the conference
room. DRS reported, to her knowledge, Staff 1 came to the
conference room to redirect Youth A and walked behind him as he
left the conference room and went toward the community area.
She further reported she had reviewed the camera footage in the
community area and only saw Youth A and Staff 1 walking
through the area. DRS allowed me to review the video footage.
An interview was completed with Staff 1. He reported he was
contacted by Staff 3 and informed that Youth A was in the
conference room. Staff 1 reported Youth A was attempting to go
AWOL. Staff 1 went to the conference room and reminded Youth
2

A that he was not allowed in this area and asked him to leave the
area, however Youth A declined and began cursing at Staff 1.
Staff 1 reported that he stood behind Youth A and talked to him as
he followed and guided him to the living room area. Youth A
walked through the living room and then went outside. Staff 1
reported he followed Youth A as he walked around the campus.
Youth A eventually made his way to the Motor City Room. Staff 1
reported Youth A was banging on the windows, pushed the
window through and crawled through the window. Staff 1 reported
some success in deescalating Youth A. Staff 1 denied hitting,
twisting the arm or stomping on the feet of Youth A.
An interview was completed with Youth A. He showed me his
feet and stated he has eczema and has to put cream on them. He
reported that the marks on his feet came from him scratching it
and that his feet are always like that. Youth A had a bandage on
his hand/wrist area and reported that it was from him breaking the
window. Youth A reported “I got mad and broke the window. I
don’t know why I broke the window”. Youth A was unable to state
when he broke the window, but confirmed it was not today. Youth
A confirmed that he was in the conference room area and should
not have been. He stated Staff 1 tried to stop him and twisted his
right arm. Youth A stated, “he tried to stop me and then I went
back into the living room”. Youth A denied that Staff 1 hit him or
stomped on his feet. He stated that he told CA that staff had
stomped on his feet, but stated he was mad and no one really
stomped his feet. Youth A denied that other youth or staff saw
Staff 1 twist his arm. He stated it happened while they were in the
conference room. Youth A was reminded that there were other
staff in the conference room and asked if they saw Staff 1 twist his
arm, and Youth A stated they did not see it.
On 06/30/2025 a voice message was left for Foster Care Worker
(FCW) advising of DCWL investigation. A request was made for a
return call with any questions or any concerns regarding the
facility. No response was received.
In-person interviews were completed with the following at
Christ Child House on 07/17/2025, unless otherwise noted.
An interview of HR Director, Clinical Director and Supervisor 1
was completed. All staff denied any concerns with Staff 1. All
also denied any knowledge of Staff 1 being physically aggressive
with Youth A or other youth at the agency.
3

An interview was completed with Staff 2. She reported she is the
cook for the agency and has been employed with CCH for 19
years. She reported she was in the conference room along with
Staff 3 when Youth A came into the area. She could not recall if it
was her or Staff 3 that called Staff 1 to let him know Youth A was
in the area. Staff 2 reported that Staff 1 came into the room and
asked Youth A to leave and he refused. She recalled that Staff 1
waited for a moment but then was able to talk Youth A into leaving
the conference room and went into the living/community area.
Staff 2 denied that other youth were in the area. She also denied
seeing Staff 1 hit, stomp on the feet of or twist the arm of Youth A.
An interview was completed with Youth B, Youth C and Youth D.
All three youth deny any concerns with Staff 1. They denied
knowledge of or seeing him being physically aggressive with
Youth A or other youth at the agency. They all further denied that
Youth A reported to them that Staff 1 stomped on his feet, hit him
or twisted his arm.
On 06/23/2025 an interview was attempted with Staff 3. He was
not available for a scheduled appointment. A voicemail message
was left for Staff 3 requesting a return call on 6/25/2025. A
telephone interview was completed with Staff 3 on 8/01/2025. He
reported he was getting coffee on the morning of 6/23/2025 and
Youth A came running into the conference room. He denied any
additional youth were in the room. He stated the agency cook
was also in the room. Staff 3 reported he called Staff 1 and
advised him that Youth A was in the conference room. He
reported Staff 1 came to get Youth A and reminded Youth A he is
not to be in this area. Staff 3 stated he stepped out of the
conference room to pour his coffee, but denied seeing Staff 1 be
physically aggressive with Youth A. He denied seeing Staff 1 hit,
twist the arm of or stomp on the feet of Youth A. Staff 3 denied
any concerns with Staff 1 and described him as one of the best
staff they have.
Documentation Review:
Christ Child House Discipline & Behavior Management Policy –
Prohibited Procedures: To ensure that residents rights are
protected, and that service is provided in a manner consistent with
best practice standards outlined below, behavior support
guidelines established by Christ Child House specifically prohibit
the use of restrictive or otherwise unacceptable actions by staff
members included, but not limited to the following criteria
examples:
-Corporal punishment of residence by staff
4

-Fear eliciting/aversive or any other restrictive/intrusive
consequences
-Physical abuse or verbal abuse of residents by staff
CCH Employee Behavior and Discipline Report –
On June 5, 2025 Staff 1 received a verbal warning for not advising
his supervisor that he would not be in to work for the day
CCH Incident Reports
Dated 6/23/2025 and written by Staff 1 and documenting defiance
and AWOL/wandering by Youth A. Youth ran off bedroom floor
without permission and went into the conference room. Youth
was running around room and failed to respond to directives.
Youth was guided out of conference room and into living room
area. Youth A then ran outside, ran around the campus and was
banging on windows. Youth went to Motor City room and pushed
the window in and climbed through the window to enter the
building. Once staff was inside, shoes of Youth A were taken as a
preventive measure due to going AWOL.
Video Footage:
Christ Child House Video showed Youth A and Staff 1 in the
community room right off from the conference room. Youth A is
seen coming into the community room through one door and then
walking out another door. Staff 1 is seen walking behind Youth A
and also exits the community room behind Youth A. There is no
camera in the conference room, thus there is no video footage of
the alleged incident.
Tour of Agency:
On 06/23/2025 a tour of the agency, specifically the area of the
alleged incident, was reviewed. No areas of concern were noted.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance. Interviews were completed with both staff and
youth at the agency and there was no evidence to support non-
compliance.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention: (b) Denial of any essential program service as
punishment. These include, but are not limited to, the following:
5

(iv) Shelter, clothing, medical care, or essential personal needs,
including culturally specific items.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency staff took shoes of Youth A.
Investigation Interviews:
In-person interviews were completed with the following at
Christ Child House on 06/23/2025, unless otherwise noted.
An interview was completed with Chief Administrator (CA). CA
also confirmed that Youth A did not have regular access to his
shoes as a AWOL deterrent.
An interview was completed with Staff 1. He confirmed that the
shoes of Youth A were removed as an AWOL deterrent. Once
back in the agency, Staff 1 reported he removed the shoes of
Youth A.
An interview was completed with Youth A. He confirmed that
Staff 1 had taken his shoes. When asked why his shoes would be
taken, he stated so he would not keep going AWOL.
In-person interviews were completed with the following at
Christ Child House on 07/17/2025, unless otherwise noted.
An interview with HR Director, Clinical Director, Staff 2 and
Supervisor 1 were completed. All staff confirmed that the shoes
of youth are taken as a deterrent to going AWOL. Each staff
stated it was a part of the agency policy and had been in place for
some time.
An interview was completed with Youth B, Youth C and Youth D.
All three youth reported that staff will take the shoes of a youth if
they keep going AWOL from the facility.
Documents Reviewed
CCH AWOL Policy - Christ Child House considers all incidents of
missing residents of high priority requiring immediate attention and
prompt reporting to the parent/guardian and appropriate
authorities; they must be reported as missing immediately when
their whereabouts are unknown. Absent Without Legal
Permission (AWOLP) is defined as a child who is placed with an
agency for care and supervision and who is absent from an
6

approved placement without legal permission. If a client is AWOL
for more than 5 days, he will be discharged from the program.
The DHHS worker has discretion to discharge a client
immediately, if they so desire. Upon residents return to the
facility, the Supervisor/Coordinator on duty will place the resident
on AWOL status which consist of: A. Resident will have his shoes
placed in the supervisors’ office B. Resident will be given his
pajamas to be worn in the facility.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance. Interviews were completed with both staff and
youth. Review of the AWOL policy documents the removal of
shoes as a deterrent to AWOL and not a form of discipline.
Technical Assistance
Review and adjustment to the AWOL policy should be made to
ensure there is no violation relative to not allowing youth access to
clothing items. Interviews with staff and youth as a part of another
special investigation, assessed removal of shoes as punitive. In
addition, there is no evidence that the removal of shoes and or
other clothing items has not deterred youth from going AWOL. In
cases where the removal of shoes does deter a youth from
running away this measure should be added to their treatment
plan.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
Section (3) The ratio formula for direct care workers shall correspond with
Description the institution’s purpose and the needs of the residents and shall
assure the continual safety, protection, and direct care and
supervision of residents.
Violation Additional Finding of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency failed to provide one-to-one staffing for Youth A as
required
Investigation Interviews:
In-person interviews were completed with the following at
Christ Child House on 06/23/2025, unless otherwise noted.
7

An interview was completed with Staff 1. He reported that Youth
A can require a one on one, but the agency was short staffed
today, so they were not able to staff Youth A as required.
An interview was completed with Youth A. He reported that he is
not staffed one to one today. He reported that he sometimes has
a staff with him all the time, but not today.
Documents Reviewed
CCH One to One Staffing Extension Request Letter for Youth A
Dated 6/17/2025. To support his continued placement and meet
his complex needs, Christ Child House respectfully requests
continued funding for intermittent 1:1 staffing of up to 18 hours per
day during waking hours, at a rate of $33.99 per hour. We
acknowledge the ongoing challenges with staffing availability and
affirm that 1:1 services will be provided as additional staffing
permits. Christ Child House will bill the Department of Health and
Human Services (DHHS) only for the hours during which 1:1
staffing is actually provided.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance. Interviews were completed with both staff and
youth. The agency has been approved for one-to-one staffing for
Youth A as additional staffing permits. Although the youth is
eligible for one to one staffing, on this date his behaviors and
needs were not escalated to require monitoring at the one to one
level and his supervision needs were being appropriately met.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
